'''''Psilocybe subaeruginosa''''' is a potent [[psychedelic mushroom]] from [[Australasia]] and [[New Zealand]], which has [[psilocybin]] and [[psilocin]] as its main active compounds.

==Taxonomy==

First [[species description|described]] in 1927 by Australian mycologist [[John Burton Cleland]],<ref name="Cleland1927"/> it was previously placed in the [[section (biology)|section]] ''Cyanescens''.<ref name="Chang1992"/> ''Cyanescens'' has since been [[deprecated]] as a section and so ''Psilocybe subaeruginosa'' now falls under the section ''Semilanceatae''.<ref name="MushObs"/>{{Better source|date=June 2015}}

A 1992 study of comparative [[morphology (biology)|morphology]], [[isozyme]] analysis and mating compatibility approaches suggested that ''P. australiana'', ''P. eucalypta'' and ''P. tasmaniana'' are [[synonym (biology)|synonyms]] of this species.<ref name="Chang1992"/> It is unclear, however, whether the study authors actually used true ''P. subaeruginosa'' for comparison, and if the results have any validity.<ref name="Stamets1996"/> Additional studies have rejected the proposed synonymy with ''P. tasmaniana'' based on differences in habitat and microscopic characters.<ref name="Johnston1995"/>

==Description==
The cap is 1–6 cm in diameter, conical to convex, tan brown, [[hygrophanous]], margin striate when moist, uplifting in age, and often with a slight [[umbo (mycology)|umbo]].  It bruises bluish where damaged. The gills are crowded, cream color when young, violet brown in age, with [[lamella (mycology)|adnate]] to adnexed attachment. The spore print is dark violet brown. The stipe is 4.5 to 22 cm long, 0.2 to 0.5 cm thick, white, bruising blue where damaged, finely striate, and equal to slightly enlarged near the base. A white cortinate partial veil soon disappears and often leaves traces in the upper stipe. The taste and odor are  [[wikt:farinaceous|farinaceous]]. The [[cystidia|cheilocystidia]] are 17–29 x 5.5–11, hyaline, fusoid-ventricose, subpyriform or mucronate, often with an elongated neck at the apex which is 2–4.5 [[µm]].  The [[cystidia|pleurocystidia]] measure 22–47 x 6–16 [[µm]] and is shaped like the cheilocystidia and also hyaline.  The spores are smooth, subellipsoid, with an apical germ pore, measuring (10) 13.2–14.3 (15.4) x 6.6–7.7 x 6–7.5 [[µm]].<ref name="Guzman"/>

<gallery>
Image:Psilocybe.subaeruginosa.cheilo.1000x.jpg|''Psilocybe subaeruginosa'' cheilocystidia 600x
Image:Psilocybe.subaeruginosa.pleuro.1000x.jpg|''Psilocybe subaeruginosa'' pleurocystidia 600x
Image:Psilocybe.subaeruginosa.spores.1000x.jpg|''Psilocybe subaeruginosa'' spores 1000x
</gallery>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Psilocybe subaeruginosa'' grows solitary to gregarious from wood such as wood chips in urban areas, pine tree plantations and woody debris in forests and gardens.<ref name="Stamets1996"/> It is common in southern parts of [[Australia]]<ref name="Chang1992"/> and [[New Zealand]]<ref name="Johnston1995"/> from April to August.<ref name="Grgurinovic1997"/>

==Alkaloid content==
[[Psilocybin]] has been isolated from this species in 0.45% yield.<ref name="Picker 1970"/> In the same study, [[psilocin]] was not detectable with the analytical methods used ([[chromatography|chromatographic]] separation and [[UV spectroscopy]]), and was estimated to be present at less than 1% of the psilocybin content.

==Similar species==
Psilocybe subaeruginosa bears similarity to a number of other common, and sometimes toxic mushrooms. In its own environment, of particular note are the mushrooms [[Pholiota communis]], the highly toxic [[Galerina marginata]] and other [[Galerina]] species.
